subject: Re: [junit] Re: Reporting,trace messages, etc
msgSnippet: Well look at it this way.  Going 10-1 and playing in a bowl game isn t good enough for some football fans anymore.  The same fans that haven t moved from one
messageBody:
Well look at it this way. Going 10-1 and playing in a bowl game isn't good enough for some
football fans anymore. The same fans that haven't moved from one side of the couch to the other.

Play on!

lee


10/1/2002 11:18:34 PM, "kentlbeck" <kentbeck@...> wrote:

>
>
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>
> From: "kentlbeck" <kentbeck@...>
> Date: Wed, 02 Oct 2002 03:18:34 -0000
> Subject:[junit] Re: Reporting,trace messages, etc
>
>
>
> --- In junit@y..., "vrntech" <vrntech@y...> wrote:
> > 3. I see JUnit is great for nesting sub-suites within a suite
> and
> > thereby creating a tree of suites. But when it comes to test
> results,
> > is there a way to get a breakup of which sub-suite had how many
> > failures from TestResult?
>
> My philosophy has always been that all the tests should run. For a
> while I had percentages of tests running in my GUIs, but then it hit
> me. It's a *BINARY* computer. Pass means everything runs. Fail means
> something doesn't run. Sort of a weakest link thing.
>
> This is also why successes aren't registered in TestResult. The sun
> came up this morning. Gravity works. Ho hum. No need to write that
> in the diary.
>
> Re: internal sucking. The TestRunner hierarchy indeed bites. No
> excuses. That's what 4.0 is for, when Erich and I get 3 days
> together. In the meantime, nothing is stopping anyone from creating
> their own (I'll be studying Michael's recent test case for ideas we
> can steal.) As for testing EJBs, that was out of scope, so I'm not
> surprised it is more difficult than necessary. A test case like
> Michael's would constitute constructive criticism.
>
> Re: MIT course. I sent the instructor of the course a response, and
> never heard anything back. Their complaints about JUnit, and their
> linking of XP and JUnit, don't make sense to me. Of course
> frameworks should come with docs, since I can't sit their with
> everyone who has downloaded JUnit. And it does. Whether they are
> good or not we can certainly debate, but they've been good enough
> for a bunch of folks. If someone wishes they had another doc as a
> beginner, they are certainly welcome to write it and we'll put it in
> the distribution.
>
> Besides, the picture on the home page of their software engineering
> course, software engineering being the quintessential team sport,
> shows a row of people staring singly at computer screens and not
> interacting with each other in any way.
>
> Kent
>
